docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Joe Biden Monday launched a broadside at the slashing budget plan of House Republicans, kicking off a campaign to try to raise the profile of GOP budget cuts and income inequality as an election-year issue.
docs.snippet: Vice President Joe Biden Monday launched a broadside at the slashing budget plan of House Republicans, kicking off a campaign to try to raise the profile of GOP budget cuts and income inequality as an election-year issue.

docs.lead_paragraph: The hunt for a health plan that would cover a particular drug or a favorite doctor proved particularly frustrating for many consumers navigating the new insurance exchanges under the federal government's health care overhaul, according to a report released Monday.

headline.main: Report: Health Exchanges' Drug Coverage Confusing
headline.print_headline: Report: Health Exchanges' Drug Coverage Confusing

docs.lead_paragraph: Three doctors at a state hospital in the Romanian capital of Bucharest have been arrested on suspicion they offered patients cheap plastic surgery and pocketed the money themselves.

headline.print_headline: Doctors Arrested in Romanian Plastic Surgery Probe

docs.snippet: Three doctors at a state hospital in the Romanian capital of Bucharest have been arrested on suspicion they offered patients cheap plastic surgery and pocketed the money themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researcher Leonid Moroz emerges from a dive off the Florida Keys and gleefully displays a plastic bag holding a creature that shimmers like an opal in the seawater.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress got back to work Monday after a two-week vacation, and it's looking like lawmakers will do what they do best: the bare minimum.

headline.main: Congress Returned to Work to Do the Bare Minimum
headline.print_headline: Congress Returned to Work to Do the Bare Minimum

docs.snippet: Congress got back to work Monday after a two-week vacation, and it's looking like lawmakers will do what they do best: the bare minimum.

docs.lead_paragraph: A recording of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling has drawn attention to his history of discrimination lawsuits, ugly pay disputes and extramarital affairs.

headline.seo: Donald Sterling Has a Public Record of Bad Behavior
headline.main: Vortex of Outrage Has Long Trailed Clippers’ Owner
headline.print_headline: Vortex of Outrage Trails Clippers’ Owner

docs.abstract: Recording of racist remarks attributed to Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling draws attention to his history of discrimination lawsuits, ugly pay disputes and extramarital affairs.
docs.snippet: A recording of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling has drawn attention to his history of discrimination lawsuits, ugly pay disputes and extramarital affairs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Physical therapy is a big recipient of national Medicare dollars — and physical therapists in Brooklyn are among the biggest billers of all, government data indicates.

headline.main: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing
headline.print_headline: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing

docs.abstract: Government data indicates that of the 10 physical therapists nationwide who were paid most by Medicare in 2012, four lived in Brooklyn, NY; practice operated by Dr Wael Bakry, the top biller, received some $4.1 million from Medicare for astounding 183,000 treatments within year; high rate has raised eyebrows among analysts who say physical therapy is far more vulnerable to fraud than other types of medicine.
docs.snippet: Physical therapy is a big recipient of national Medicare dollars — and physical therapists in Brooklyn are among the biggest billers of all, government data indicates.

byline.original: By JULIE CRESWELL and ROBERT GEBELOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: A report criticizes federal pay-for-performance policies as being unfair to doctors and hospitals that treat poor people.

headline.main: Health Law’s Pay Policy Is Skewed, Panel Finds
headline.print_headline: Health Law’s Pay Policy Is Skewed, Panel Finds

docs.abstract: Report commissioned by the Obama administration from nonprofit organization National Quality Forum finds that federal policies to reward high-quality health care are unfairly penalizing doctors and hospitals that treat large numbers of poor people; report recommends sweeping changes in payment policy.
docs.snippet: A report criticizes federal pay-for-performance policies as being unfair to doctors and hospitals that treat poor people.
